question: Question_02_(b)
statement:
Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answers and show all your work.
Simplification of answers is not required.

Find the numbers \emph{b} such that the average value of the function
$f(x) = 3x^{2}-6x + 2$ on the interval $[0,b]$ is equal to 0.
sols:
The questions asks for when $f_{av} = 0$. Plugging this into the formula
in the hint gives

\begin{align*}
f_{av} &= \frac{1}{b-0}\int_{0}^{b} (3x^{2}-6x + 2 )\, dx \\
&= \frac{1}{b}\left.x^{3} - 3x^{2} + 2x \right|_{0}^{b}\\
&= \frac{1}{b}(b^{3} - 3b^{2} + 2b)\\
&= b^{2} - 3b + 2\\
&= (b-2)(b-1)
\end{align*}

and so we have that $b = 1$ or $b=2$ completing the question.
hints:
The average value of a function on an interval is

\[f_{av} = \frac{1}{b-a}\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\, dx\]
